posts.body:
Pearl Gibbs

One of the most prominent Indigenous Australian activists and a member of the Aborigines Progressive Association (APA), Pearl Gibbs’ (1901-1983) work was essential in forging links between the Aboriginal movement and the women’s movement in Australia.

Born near Sydney, Australia to a White father and a Ngemba mother, Gibbs found a job as a domestic laborer at age 16. Here she met other Aboriginal women (and girls) working as domestic laborers by the Aborigines Protection Board (a state-run institute that controlled nearly every aspect of the lives of indigenous Australians) and helped them make representations to the Board about their working conditions.

Her voice in activism grew. In 1930, she helped run a camp to support unemployed Aboriginal workers and organized a strike for Aboriginal peapickers. She gave speeches the attracted huge crowds and helped organize the Day of Mourning protests. She spoke for the Committee for Aboriginal Citizen Rights and was the first Aboriginal woman to make a radio broadcast.

All of this work was done during a time when indigenous Australians had very few rights and were closely monitored by the police. The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) closely monitored Gibbs.

Throughout her life, Gibbs continued to found and lead a number of organizations dedicated to giving power to Aboriginal Australians and forged connections between this movement, the labor movement, and women’s movement.

These groundbreaking articles from High Country News expose the use of expropriated Indigenous land to create and fund 52 Institutions of higher education 10.7 million acres, usually without any recompense to the 245 nations on that land.

posts.body:
Albert Namatjira

Born Elea, Namatjira (1902-1959) was an Aboriginal artist from Central Australia and considered the most famous Indigenous Australian of his generation.

Born at Hermannsburg Lutheran Mission to the Western Arrarnta people, Namatjira showed an interest in art early. As a young boy, his parents adopted Christianity and changed his name. He received a Western-style upbringing on the mission but returned to the Arrernte community at age 13 for initiation.

At 18, he married a Kukatja woman, with whom he had 8 children. His wife was from the wrong skin group and he was ostracised as a result. He worked a variety of jobs around Australia, including as a camel driver, blacksmith, and carpenter. It was here that he began to develop as an artist.

He was trained in painting by Australian artist Rex Battarbee (today most famous for having trained Namatjira). Namatjira’s paintings were landscape watercolors using colors of traditional Australian art in a Western aesthetic. He also focused on sacred sites and objects (Tjurunga).

His increasing success and fame internationally did not work out as well as it should have. He tried multiple times to buy land and build houses for his extended family, but legal protections for White people and cheating sellers stymied him. Though he was one of Australia’s greatest artists, he lived in a squalid shack. When this became known it causes a wave of public outrage.

Part of the problem was that he and his wife, like all Aboriginal people, were legal wards of the state. At 55, he was encouraged to apply for and received Australian citizenship, the first Northern Territory Aboriginal person to get this. This gave him and his wife–but not the rest of his family or people–the right to vote and buy alcohol, though he still had limited land rights. Namatjira supplied alcohol to other adults in his community, but when one died he was held responsible for giving alcohol to a ‘ward’ and sentenced to prison. He died soon after serving his sentence.

Ajantzi Waterhole
(c. 1937)

Central Australian Gorge (c. 1940)

Ghost Gum Glen Helen (1950)

October 22nd, 1633: Ming Dynasty China defeats the Dutch East India Company after the Company launches a surprise attack. The Battle of Liaoluo Bay kept the Taiwan Strait in Asian hands.

posts.body:
Jacob Barsimson

Jacob Barsimson, or יעקב ברסימסון‎, was the first known Jewish person in New York.

Barsimson traveled from Europe in 1654 and settled in what was then the Dutch colony of New Amsterdam. He was soon followed by 23 Jewish people fleeing the Portuguese Inquisition in Brazil, widely considered the starting point of Jewish-American history. Together, they started the first Jewish settlement in what would eventually become the United States.

Though he was a man of little means, Barsimson fought for his rights against much stronger and wealthier opponents. He fought to be allowed to either stand guard like others or at least not be taxed for failing to do so (as he wasn’t allowed). When the governor essentially said, “if you don’t like it, you can leave”, they appealed to his superiors, who condemned this decision.

He was also once summoned to court on a Saturday and did not appear, but was given pardon, “though defendant is absent, yet no default is entered against him, as he was summoned on his Sabbath.”

Today, the Jewish community is a pillar of the people and the culture of New York City. Jacob Barsimsom was the man who started it all.

posts.body:
Henry Odera Oruka

Henry Odera Oruka (1944-1995) was a Kenyan philosopher with a focus on preserving the knowledge of indigenous thinkers in Africa.

Born and primarily educated in Kenya, he went to Uppsala University in Sweden, where he studied Meteorology, Geography, Geodesy, and Philosophy. He graduated a year early and moved to the USA where he continued his studies in Philosophy, eventually obtaining both a master’s and a PhD in the subject.

In 1970, he returned to Kenya and began reforming and teaching at the University of Nairobi. At the time, philosophy was mainly taught as an extension of Religious Studies. Odera Oruka spearheaded a years-long struggle to separate the subjects and begin treating African Philosophy as worthy of study. Upon his success, he was appointed the Founder-Chairman of the Department of Philosophy. Unfortunately, after his death the two subjects have once again been merged.

Odera Oruka’s philosophy has these basic principles:

  1. Poverty and hunger in Africa are the greatest constraints to mental development
  2. Ideas about the levels of civilization and philosophic gifts of certain races are a cultural and racial myth that serve to work against Africa
  3. Appearance is an obstacle to intellectual activity, resulting in education that reinforces rather than dismantles prejudice, racism, sexism, etc.
  4. An independent African philosophy has always existed and is as worthy of study as European philosophy.

In the 1970s, he began to pursue that last point in his Philosophic Sagacity project, designed to preserve the philosophy of traditional Kenyan sages.

posts.body:
Julius Nyerere

An activist, educator, and politician from Tanzania, Julia Kyerere (1922-1999) is sometimes called the “Father of the Nation”. He promoted socialism, anti-colonialism, and stability in Africa.

Born in Mwitongo, Tanganyika (the country the would later become Tanzania), to the king of the Zanaki people, one of the smallest of the 120 tribes in what was at the time a British colony. He received an education both in Africa and in Edinburgh, pursuing a teaching career and beginning to develop his political philosophy.

He argued that capitalism was alien to Africa and that Africa could better be served by its natural “African socialism”. He was elected president of the Tanganyika African Association (later the Tanganyika African National Union; TANU) in 1953 and became the de facto head of the independence movement.

Ideologically, Nyerere emulated the non-violent methods of Gandhi and said that while the country should be led but indigenous Africans, it would not eject the European and Asian minorities that lived there–Nyerere dreamt of a society that was both proudly African and multicultural.

In 1958, he led the TANU’s participation in a series of elections, getting both indigenous Africans and European and Asian sympathies elected, creating a legislative council dominated by the party.

With this political power, TANU began a peaceful transition to independence, a democratic African government focused on African solidarity, dismantling the lingering effects of colonialism, and racial justice.

There is more to say about his life–the policies he put forward, his impacts, the Arusha Declaration, his controversial methods for maintaining power. But his creation of the United Republic of Tanzania–a strong and independent country that remained stable when its neighbors were weak–will always make him one of the most noteworthy men in recent history.

posts.body:
Ndiadiane Ndiaye

The (possibly mythical) Ndiadiane Ndiaye was the founder of the Wolof empire. Stories of his ancestry vary but agree that he was the son of a foreign nobility. His first words were always in Pulaar rather than Wolof.

As the legend goes, he was born Ahmad Abu Bakr (14th century), and he fled his family in rejection of an arranged marriage and lived for three years in a cave near a river. When some fishermen got into a quarrel over some wood, Ndiaye came out of the water and divided it fairly before anything could escalate to bloodshed. In recognition of his wisdom, he was made king of Waalo, where he reigned for a few years.

When he learned of a plot against him, Ndiaye voluntarily left and settled in Wolof. It was here that he founded the Wolof Empire, bringing together landowners and disparate nations. It was a voluntary union between the Wolof, Serer, and Toucouleur kingdoms (different stories claim his ancestry in some or all of these groups).

The Wolof (or Jolof, Wollof, Djolof, etc.) Empire was a Senegambian state that grew peacefully and without any conquest. Landowners and existing power structures remained in power. Their political system was, according to Portuguese explores, very advanced. Their culture was incredible and included artisans, craftspeople, and griots (a historian/musician in charge of preserving oral tradition and advising leaders). While women’s rights in marriage were limited, they were well represented in politics in multiple offices.

When some fishermen got into a quarrel over some wood, Ndiaye came out of the water and divided it fairly before anything could escalate to bloodshed. In recognition of his wisdom, he was made king of Waalo, where he reigned for a few years.

When he learned of a plot against him, Ndiaye voluntarily left and settled in Wolof. It was here that he founded the Wolof Empire, bringing together landowners and disparate nations. It was a voluntary union between the Wolof, Serer, and Toucouleur kingdoms (different stories claim his ancestry in some or all of these groups).

The Wolof (or Jolof, Wollof, Djolof, etc.) Empire was a Senegambian state that grew peacefully and without any conquest. Landowners and existing power structures remained in power. Their political system was, according to Portuguese explores, very advanced. Their culture was incredible and included artisans, craftspeople, and griots (a historian/musician in charge of preserving oral tradition and advising leaders). While women’s rights in marriage were limited, they were well represented in politics in multiple offices.

posts.body:
Mama Cax

An American-Haitian disabled rights activist and fashion model, Cacsmy Brutus (1989-2019) a famous face of often marginally groups in the high-glamour world of fashion.

Born in Brooklyn and raised in Haiti, Cax was diagnosed with osteosarcoma and lung cancer. Treatments lasted for years and often didn’t work, and at 16 her right leg had to be amputated.

Though at first she hid her prosthetic leg, she did not let it slow her down. Cax received a bachelor’s and a master’s in International Studies and was working in the office of the Mayor of New York City when she started modeling.

Cax walked the runway for Chromat and Rihanna’s Fenty Beauty and appeared on ad campaigns for Tommy Hilfiger and Sephora. In 2018, she walked at New York Fashion Week and appeared on the cover of Teen Vogue. She was the face of Olay sunscreen and participated in the New York Marathon in a wheelchair.

All of these amazing accomplishments were things she did while still sick, and in December 2019, at the age of 30, she died from blood clots in her lung.

Mama Cax was a trailblazing Black woman determined not to let any circumstances keep her from her place in the spotlight or miss out on any experiences.

Image Description: three color photographs of model Mama Cax, a Black woman with no hair. In the first, she is wearing a black and yellow athleisure outfit. She is standing on a runway with a prosthetic leg and canes. In the second, she is wearing sunglasses and a bikini and is standing against a blue wall with no prosthetics. In the third, she is sitting in a handcycle at the NYC marathon, wearing a blue tracksuit and helmet, raising a peace sign in the air.

posts.summary: Things That Weren't Invented/Discovered By White People
posts.body:
Things That Weren’t Invented/Discovered By White People

  1. Kites: First invented to send messages over long distances, kites were invented by Lu Ban, a 5th century BCE engineer from the Zhou Dynasty, China.
  2. Dagger-axe: Also called a ge, the dagger-axe is an agricultural tool and a weapon. The first were made of stone found in the Longshan culture (3000-2000 BCE) at Henan in what is now China.
  3. Swords: The very first weapons that could be called swords were from 3300 BCE, during Turkey’s Bronze Age. Made of arsenical bronze and inlaid with silver, the first were unearthed in Arslantepe.

posts.body:
Shango

Shango (14th century?) was a political leader of the Oyo Empire, later deified.

The Oyo Empire was a powerful Yoruba empire in West Africa, in what is now Benin and Nigeria. It was known for its outstanding organizational and administrative skills and gained wealth as a center of trade. It existed from c. 1300-1896 CE.

Shango was the third oba (king) of Oyo after the previous was disposed. Shango was known for being powerful and militaristic, and he brought prosperity to the empire. His reign ended when his palace was struck and destroyed by lightning.

He was then defied as an Orisha, a Yoruba deity, and also appears in other West African diasporic religions, such as Haitian Vodou, Louisiana Voodoo, Brazilian Candomblé, and Folk Catholicism (where he is syncretized with either Saint Barbara or Saint Jerome).

Shango was the god of thunder and lightning, typically viewed as the most powerful of the Orisha pantheon. His colors are white and red, his day is Thursday, and his weapons of choice are Thunderstones (which he throws down at people who anger him) and the oxê, a double ax similar to a labrys. You can see the shape of the oxê on the head of the statue, pictured above.

Shango’s name changes between countries and traditions. Some variations and alternatives of it are Sango, Ṣàngó, Changó, Xangô, Jakuta, Nzazi, Hevioso, and Siete Rayos.

posts.body:
Princess Sela

One of the first known female pirates, Princess Sela (active c. 400-420 CE) was a Norwegian princess. This would be centuries before the Viking Age hit Scandanavia.

Only a single sentence in the Gesta Danorum attests to her existence.

Deinde sororem eius, Selam nomine, piraticis exercitam rebus ac bellici peritam muneris, persecutus occidit.

Then he (Horwendill) pursued that (King Koller of Norway)’s sister, with the name Sela, skilled in piracy and experience in war and killed her.

From this, we know that Sela was a princess, brother to the king, and a respected and feared pirate on her own merit. She was killed in battle by a political rival, perhaps fearing her reprisal for his regicide.

posts.body:
Martinique Woman by Malvina Hoffman

On View: Luce Visible Storage and Study Center, 5th Floor

Although ostensibly a portrait head of a woman from the Caribbean island of Martinique, this sculpture is one of a number of heads based on Malvina Hoffman’s travels through Africa about 1928.

posts.summary: Lt. General José Antonio de la Caridad Maceo y Grajales
posts.body:
Lt. General José Antonio de la Caridad Maceo y Grajales

With Hispanic Heritage Month ending tomorrow, we turn to El Titán de Bronce (The Bronze Titan), a guerilla leader in the Cuban War of Independence.

Maceo’s (1845-1896) father was a Venezuelan farmer and his mother was an Afro-Cuban woman of Dominican descent. Maceo credits his father for his ability to fire arms, but his mother for his leadership style and sense of order.

In autumn 1868, Maceo’s entire family (including his mother) left their home and went into the woods to join the Cuban rebellion. Maceo enlisted as a private and quickly rose through the ranks due to his bravery and ability to outmaneuver the Spanish Army. Maceo participated in more than 500 battles, receiving over 25 war injuries, none of which slowed him down.

His promotions were slower than they should have been, due to classism and racism, but his actions gave him the respect of many soldiers. The Spanish also published divide propaganda with attempted to create the impression that Maceo was trying to start a racial war against white Cubans, making the people on his side distrustful of him.

This war, the 10 years war, ended against Maceo’s wishes. He argued that none of the objectives of the revolution had been achieved, namely the abolition of slavery and Cuban independence. Within days of the truce (which he did not recognize) being signed, Maceo continued fighting.

Maceo traveled around the Caribbean for a while, fending off multiple assassination attempts and planning for another revolution. In 1895, Maceo returned to Cuba and began to collect an army. Maceo was second-in-command of the Cuban Liberation Army and alternated his men between guerilla and open warfare, successfully due to Maceo’s implementation of military order.

Maceo was killed in a firefight after his doctor sold their location to the enemy, but his principles live on. Rather than an angry man looking for violence, Maceo was the epitome of a principled man fighting against oppression and imperialism in all its forms.

posts.body:
Beatrice Potter Webb

An English sociologist, socialist, and social reformed, Marth Beatrice Potter, Baroness Passfield (1858-1943) was the person who coined the term collective bargaining, now essential for trade unions attempting to secure workers’ rights.

[The Right Honourable Lady Passfield, FBA]

The eighth of nine daughters to a politically connected family, Potter was largely self-educated. She and her husband helped form the Fabian Society, a British socialist organization that is still active today.

Potter was a writer–she wrote books and pamphlets on socialism and the co-operative movement, which she cited as a major influence on her philosophy. It was in these books that she coined ‘collective bargaining.’ She helped found the London School of Economics and Political Science. In 1902, she began a salon for vegetarian socialists.

She served for four years on the Royal Commission on the Poor Laws and Relief of Distress 1905-1909 and was the lead author on the minority report. It was a dissenting report that argued for a radically different system, a welfare state that could

secure a national minimum of civilised life … open to all alike, of both sexes and all classes, by which we meant sufficient nourishment and training when young, a living wage when able-bodied, treatment when sick, and modest but secure livelihood when disabled or aged.

posts.summary: Things That Weren't Invented/Discovered By White People
posts.body:
Things That Weren’t Invented/Discovered By White People

  1. Baby bottles: History will often say they were invented in 1841 by C.M. Windship. In reality, Iroquois made bottles to feed infants for centuries before this.
  2. Coffee: Coffee was first domesticated and made into an energy drink by Ethiopians.
  3. Lassos: Actually first used by the Lenape, whose territory is present-day Delaware, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, and New York, to trap game, before they brought it to Texas.

posts.body:
Mary Two-Axe Earley

A woman’s and First Nations rights activist, Mary Two-Axe (1911-1996) helped establish the Equal Rights for Indian Women organization and the Québec Native Women’s Association.

Two-Axe was a Mohawk and Oneida woman from the Kahnawake reserve in Québec, Canada. She was raised by her grandparents at Kahnawake. At age 18, she moved to Brooklyn, New York for work. When she was 29, she married an Irish-American man named Edward Earley.

The Indian Act, a Canadian act of Parliament first passed in 1876, stripped Two-Axe (and her two children) of their Native status because she had married a “non-status” man. Not only was this a racist attempt to “define away” Native people, but it was also misogynistic–the same thing did not happen to a Native man who married a “non-status” woman. Because of this, she wasn’t allowed to own land on the reserve (even if she inherited it), vote in reserve elections, or be buried in the reserve cemetery.

After a friend in a similar situation died, Two-Axe began campaigning across Canada. In 1967, she founded the Equal Rights for Indian Women Association (later known as Indian Rights for Indian Women). She submitted a brief to the Royal Commission on the Status of Women and led a group of 30 Mohawk women to speak. As a result of her actions, the Indian Act was amended to not discriminate on gender.

Two-Axe was also targeted by the men who led the Kahnawake reserve. In 1969, she tried to move back into the house she inherited from her grandmother but was told she wasn’t welcome. She had to gift it to her daughter and live there as a guest.

In 1974, Two-Axe co-founded the Québec Native Women’s Association and led a group of 60 women from the Kahnawake reserve to attend the International Women’s Year Conference in Mexico. In that time, the band council attempted to evict her–she had to publicize the situation to get the eviction notice withdrawn.

She spoke at a first ministers conference and helped pass Bill C-31 to amend the Indian Act, allowing women like Two-Axe to finally have their status reinstated–Two-Axe was the first woman to get it and was followed by 16,000 other women and 46,000 descendants.

A strong and dedicated woman, Two-Axe was hurt for her love and was isolated in her struggles as a Native woman, without the support she ought to have received from Native men and non-Native women. Despite this, her actions have been massively important in First Nations history.

posts.summary: Things That Weren't Invented/Discovered By White People
posts.body:
Things That Weren’t Invented/Discovered By White People

  1. Vulcanization: First invented by the Olmecs of what is now Mexico, vulcanization is a method of processing rubber. Charles Goodyear (of Goodyear tires) typically claims this invention, but he didn’t reinvent it until the 19th century.
  2. Snowshoes: Snowshoes were invented and used by the Native American and First Nation groups in North America.
  3. Compass: The Olmecs certainly understood magnetization, and some evidence is beginning to suggest they invented the compass a thousand years before even China did.

Things That Weren’t Invented/Discovered By White People

  1. Vulcanization: First invented by the Olmecs of what is now Mexico, vulcanization is a method of processing rubber. Charles Goodyear (of Goodyear tires) typically claims this invention, but he didn’t reinvent it until the 19th century.
  2. Snowshoes: Snowshoes were invented and used by the Native American and First Nation groups in North America.
  3. Compass: The Olmecs certainly understood magnetization, and some evidence is beginning to suggest they invented the compass a thousand years before even China did.
